original_table_html:
| Term                      | Definition                                                                                  |
|---------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Geographical pricing**  | Setting prices for customers located in different parts of the country or world.            |
| **FOB-origin pricing**    | Pricing in which goods are placed free on board a carrier; the customer pays the freight from the factory to the destination. |
| **Uniform-delivered pricing** | Pricing in which the company charges the same price plus freight to all customers, regardless of their location. |
| **Zone pricing**          | Pricing in which the company sets up two or more zones. All customers within a zone pay the same total price; the more distant the zone, the higher the price. |
| **Basing-point pricing**  | Pricing in which the seller designates some city as a basing point and charges all customers the freight cost from that city to the customer. |
| **Freight-absorption pricing** | Pricing in which the seller absorbs all or part of the freight charges in order to get the desired business. | Throughout most of history, prices were set by negotiation between buyers and sellers.
summary_markdown: This table outlines various geographical pricing strategies used in business. These strategies address how transportation costs are factored into the final price for customers situated in different locations. FOB-origin pricing places the freight cost responsibility on the customer from the factory onwards. Conversely, uniform-delivered pricing applies a single price plus freight to all customers, irrespective of their distance. Zone pricing categorizes customers into zones, with prices increasing for more distant zones, while all customers within a single zone pay the same total price. Basing-point pricing designates a specific city as a reference point, with all customers charged freight costs from that city. Finally, freight-absorption pricing involves the seller covering some or all of the transportation costs to secure business.
